block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
MUSIC

APPEL FARM ARTS AND MUSIC CENTER Appel Farm Arts and Music Festival, featuring Mary Chapin Carpenter and Richard Thompson, among others. Saturday, 11:30 a.m. to 8 p.m. Tickets (advance): $28; $24 for students and older people; free for children 12 and under. 457 Shirley Road, Elmer. (800) 394-1211.

CAPE MAY CONVENTION HALL Cape May Music Festival. Through June 25. Bruce Molsky and the Big Hoedown band. Today at 8 p.m. The Cape May Festival Orchestra, with Brian Lewis, violinist. Thursday at 8 p.m. Mary Wilson and the Supremes and the Cape May Festival Pops Orchestra. Next Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 for each concert; $10 for older people; $5 for students. Beach Drive and Stockton Street, Cape May. The New York Chamber Ensemble. Tuesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Episcopal Church of the Advent. Washington and Franklin Streets, Cape Map. (609) 884-5404.

An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
MUSIC

APPEL FARM ARTS AND MUSIC CENTER Appel Farm Arts and Music Festival, featuring Mary Chapin Carpenter and Richard Thompson, among others. Saturday, 11:30 a.m. to 8 p.m. Tickets (advance): $28; $24 for students and older people; free for children 12 and under. 457 Shirley Road, Elmer. (800) 394-1211.

CAPE MAY CONVENTION HALL Cape May Music Festival. Through June 25. Bruce Molsky and the Big Hoedown band. Today at 8 p.m. The Cape May Festival Orchestra, with Brian Lewis, violinist. Thursday at 8 p.m. Mary Wilson and the Supremes and the Cape May Festival Pops Orchestra. Next Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 for each concert; $10 for older people; $5 for students. Beach Drive and Stockton Street, Cape May. The New York Chamber Ensemble. Tuesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Episcopal Church of the Advent. Washington and Franklin Streets, Cape Map. (609) 884-5404.
MORROW MEMORIAL METHODIST CHURCH Mostly Music concert featuring music of Mozart, Enescu and Brahms. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $20; $18 for older people. 600 Ridgewood Road, Maplewood. (973) 762-8486.

MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN HUNGARIAN FOUNDATION Hungarian Twilight Musical Concert. Saturday at 6 p.m. Tickets: $5. Hungarian Heritage Center Courtyard, 300 Somerset Street, New Brunswick. (732) 846-5777.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER United Way Showcase. Wednesday at 7 p.m. Victoria Theater. Tickets: $12; $7 for children. ''Absolut Sounds of the City 2000,'' outdoor music series. Thursday evenings through Aug. 31. Holland Tunnel Project, the Choro Quartet and Beethova Obas, Haitian troupadour. Thursday, 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. Theater Square. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.

OCEAN GROVE SUMMER CONCERT SERIES Through Sept. 9. ''The Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber.'' Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 (reserved); $20 (regular admission). The Great Auditorium, two blocks from the ocean at the intersection of Pilgrim and Ocean Pathways, Ocean Grove. (732) 988-0645.

OPERA AT FLORHAM ''Die Fledermaus.'' Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $35; $31.50 for older people. Fairleigh Dickinson University, Dreyfuss Theater, Florham-Madison campus, Madison. (973) 443-8620.

PNC BANK ARTS CENTER Styx, REO Speedwagon, Eddie Money. Today at 7 p.m. Tickets: $17.50 to $45. Martina McBride. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $35 and $25. Exit 116, off the Garden State Parkway, Holmdel. (201) 507-8900.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY RICHARDSON AUDITORIUM Westminster Conservatory of Music will present a family concert featuring the Wesminster Community Orchestra and the Westminster Children's Choirs. Saturday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $10; $8 for students and older people. A second performance at 8 p.m. on Saturday includes the Westminster Community Chorus. Tickets: $25 for preferred seating; $10 for served seating. Alexander Hall, Princeton. (609) 258-5000.

RIDGEWOOD UNITED METHODIST CHURCH The New Jersey Choral Society presents ''Night and Day,'' a pops concert of opera, operetta, Broadway tunes and more. Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $18; $15 for students and older people. 100 Dayton Street, Ridgewood. (201) 652-3590.
TEMPLE EMANU-EL Mostly Music concert featuring music of Mozart, Enescu and Brahms. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $20; $18 for older people.756 East Broad Street, Westfield. (973) 762-8486.

TRENTON WAR MEMORIAL Blood, Sweat and Tears, featuring David Clayton-Thomas will open 2000 Heritage Days Festival. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $27, $25 and $22. Lafayette and Willow Streets, Trenton. (973) 624-3713, ext. 255 or (609) 984-8400.
WATCHUNG ARTS CENTER The Boilermakers, jazz ensemble. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12. Watchung Circle, 18 Stirling Road, Watchung. (908) 753-0190.
Theater

CENTENARY STAGE COMPANY Spring Festival of Shows, featuring ''Tom Sawyer.'' Today at 4:30 p.m. ''Anything Goes.'' Today at 1 p.m. ''West Side Story.'' Today at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $8; $6 for children under 12. Centenary College, 400 Jefferson Street, Hackensack. (908) 979-0900.
CIRCLE PLAYERS ''A View From the Bridge,'' by Arthur Miller. Friday and Saturday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $12. 416 Victoria Avenue, Piscataway. (732) 968-7555.

ELIZABETH PLAYHOUSE ''Of Human Bondage,'' by Karon Semones. Through next Sunday. Friday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m.; next Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $8; $6 for students and older people; $5 on Fridays. 1100 East Jersey Street, Elizabeth. (908) 355-0077.

FIRST PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH The East Lynne Company presents ''Nothing Matters,'' about Ambrose Bierce (journalist) in Mexico. Wednesday through July 8. Wednesday through Saturday performances at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $16; $14 for students and older people. 500 Hughes Street, Cape May. (609) 884-5898.

GEORGE STREET PLAYHOUSE ''Ancestral Voices,'' by A. R. Gurney. Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $22 to $40. The Next Stage Festival. Through June 11. ''1001 Nights.'' Today at 7 p.m. ''Waiting for Tadashi.'' Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $10. 9 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-7717.

HUNTERDON HILLS PLAYHOUSE ''Mary, Mary,'' Jean Kerr's comedy. Through June 30. Monday through Saturday luncheon performances at 11 a.m., $35.50 and $39.50; Saturdays at 6:30 p.m., $43 and $47; Sundays at 3:30 p.m., $41.50 and $45.50. Reservations required. Exit 12 off Routes 78 and 22, Perryville. (800) 447-7313.
KELSEY THEATER ''2000 Footsteps!'' performed by the Mercer Dance Ensemble. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $9 to $18. Mercer County Community College, 1200 Trenton Road, Trenton. (609) 584-9444.

McCARTER THEATER ''L'Universe,'' featuring the Flying Karamazov Brothers. Wednesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12 (standing room only). Center for the Performing Arts, 91 University Place, Princeton. (609) 258-2787.

NEW JERSEY REPERTORY COMPANY ''Octet,'' Mark Dunn comic-drama. Through June 18. Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $25. Opening night on Friday with reception: $35. Lumia Theater, 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.
Museums and Galleries

AMERICAN LABOR MUSEUM ''Vital Vestiges,'' a photodocumentary of the Paterson historic district's ruins. ''What is Industrial Hygiene?'' photo and illustration exhibit on loan from the American Industrial Hygiene Association in Virginia. Through June 25. Hours: Wednesdays through Saturdays, 1 to 4 p.m.; other times by appointment. Botto House National Landmark, 83 Norwood Street, Haledon. (973) 595-7953.

ATRIUM ART GALLERY ''Five Views,'' featuring landscape photography. Through July 21. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Morris County Administration and Records Building, Morristown. (973) 285-6120.

BRION GALLERIES ''New Work by Oil Painter Cathy Lang.'' Through June 25. ''Alien Beings of Uncertain Origin,'' one-man show of monotypes by Stephen McKenzie. Saturday through Aug. 27. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. 1293 Route 179, Lambertville. (609) 397-7030.

COOPER GALLERY ''The Illuminated Woman,'' a solo exhibition of paintings and drawings by Eileen Kennedy-Dyne. Tuesday through July 1. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 7 p.m. 295 Grove Street, Jersey City. (201) 451-1074.
EVERGREEN GALLERY ''Intimate Landscapes in oil,'' by Marie Salvato. Through Saturday. Hours: Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 308 Morris Avenue, Spring Lake. (732) 449-4488.

FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON UNIVERSITY ''Inner and Outer Reality,'' mixed media exhibit, by Ruth Rintel. Through Friday. Hours: Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. Edward Williams Gallery, 150 Kotte Place, Hackensack. (201) 692-2449.

GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE ''Spring Exhibition'' featuring Red Grooms: sculpture; Bill Barrett: sculpture and painting; and Andrzej Pitynski: partisans. Through July 2. Hours: Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday by appointment. 18 Fairgrounds Road, Hamilton Township. (609) 586-0616.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART ''Robert Forman: 'Narratives in Thread' and 'Huichol Art in the Collection of Robert Forman.' '' Through June 18. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

JERSEY CITY MUSEUM ''Joan Semmel: Recent Paintings.'' Through Saturday. Hours: Tuesday through Saturday, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Wednesday, 10:30 a.m.to 8 p.m. 472 Jersey Avenue, Jersey City. (201) 547-4514.

LIBERTY SCIENCE CENTER ''Lakota Wolf Preserve,'' photographs by Dan Bacon. Through June 18. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9:30 to 5:30 p.m. Environment Level, Liberty State Park, 251 Phillip Street, Jersey City. (201) 451-0006, extension 295.

MIDDAY GALLERY ''Family, Friends and Favorite Places,'' exhibition of art works by Helen Frank. Through June 11. Hours: Tuesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 8 North Dean Street, Englewood. (201) 568-4454.

MONMOUTH MUSEUM ''New Jersey's Pinelands: Water in the Balance.'' Through Sept. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4. 761 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft. (732) 747-2266.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM ''Untamed Spirits: Animal Imagery in Native American Art.'' Through July 30. Will Barnet: A Timeless World. Through Aug. 20. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for members and children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MORRIS MUSEUM ''Fresh Perspectives.'' Through June 5.''The Collected Century, 1900 to 2000.'' Through June 11. ''Ice Age,'' featuring casts of mammals from the Pleistocene epoch. Through June 18. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for older people and children under age 3. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.

MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN HUNGARIAN FOUNDATION ''Munkacsy in America,'' paintings by Mihaly Munkacsy. Through June 18. Donation: $5. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. 300 Somerset Street, New Brunswick. (732) 846-5777.

NEW JERSEY CENTER FOR VISUAL ARTS ''Forgotten Places,'' recent paintings and digital prints by Liz Demaree. Through June 9. ''On the Horizon: Landscape at the Millennium.'' Through June 11. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, noon to 4 p.m.; Thursdays, 7 to 9 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. Palmer Gallery, 68 Elm Street, Summit. (908) 273-9121.

NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''History's Mysteries,'' interactive exhibition. Through June. ''Dining In, Dining Out,'' featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks. Through summer, 2001. ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles,'' about the history of baseball in Newark. Through Summer 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 52 Park Place, Newark. (973) 596-8500.

NEW JERSEY STATE MUSEUM ''Forgotten Gateway: The Abandoned Building of Ellis Island,'' photographs by Larry Racioppo. Through June 30. ''Nikon's Small World, 1999-2000.'' Through Tuesday. ''Building a Collection: Fine Art at the New Jersey State Museum.'' Saturday through Aug. 20. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Free. 205 West State Street, Trenton. (609) 292-6464.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''The Art of Ink in American 2000: International Contemporary Calligraphy.'' Through July 9. ''Year of the Dragon: The Calligraphy of Wang Fangyu.'' Through Nov. 12. ''From Tabletop to TV Tray: China and Glass in America, 1880-1980.'' Through June 18. ''Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning.'' Through December. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays (after hours) until 8:30 p.m. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY ART MUSEUM ''Curator's Choice: Recent Acquisitions.'' Through June 6. Photographs by Barbara Bosworth. Through June 18. ''A Window Into Collecting American Folk Art: The Edward Duff Balken Collection.'' Through June 18. ''Flora and Fauna in Chinese Painting.'' Through July 30. Yayoi Kusama: Early Drawings From the Collection of Richard Castellane. Through July 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Princeton campus. (609) 258-3788.

PUFFIN CULTURAL FORUM ''Terra Infirma: Art, Activisim and the Environment.'' Through June 24. Hours: Wednesday through Saturday, 1 to 5 p.m.; or by appointment. 20 East Oakdene Avenue, Teaneck. (201) 836-8923.

TRENTON CITY MUSEUM ''Guccione, the Painter: A Retrospective of His Life's Work.'' Through June 11. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. Ellarslie, Cadwalader Park, Trenton. (609) 989-3632.

WHEATON VILLAGE ''American Glass: 1900-2000,'' featuring more than 100 industrial and decorative pieces. Through Oct. 22. ''2000 Flowers.'' Saturday through June 11. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552, extension 2756.
For Children

FORUM THEATER COMPANY ''Narnia; the Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,'' based on the ''Chronicles of Narnia'' by C. S. Lewis. Through June 10. Saturdays at 11 a.m. Tickets: $9. 314 Main Street, Metuchen. (732) 548-0582.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART ''Spring Fever,'' workshops and classes for children and adults, including KinderArt, Cartooning Around, Collage Kids and more. Through June 8. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Where in the Universe Is Carmen Sandiego?'' at the Alice and Leonard Dreyfuss Planetarium. Through October. Saturdays and Sundays, 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. Tickets: $3; $2 for members; $1 for children and older people. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6355.

STONY BROOK-MILLSTONE WATERSHED ''Birdwatching for Beginners.'' Thursdays, June 1, 8 and 15, from 7:30 p.m. to 9 p.m, and Saturdays, June 10 and 17, from 8 a.m. to noon. Fee: $45. Pre-registration is required. Buttinger Nature Center, 31 Titus Mill Road, Pennington. (609) 737-7592.

TRAILSIDE NATURE AND SCIENCE CENTER National Trails Day; guided nature walks along trails in the Watchung Reservation or Lenape Park. Saturday at 10 a.m. Pre-registration is required. Planetarium Show. Today and next Sunday, 2 p.m. and 3:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $2.55 for older people. 452 New Providence Road, Mountainside. (908) 789-3670.
Spoken Word

BARNES & NOBLE Robin Rielly, author of ''Mighty Midgets at War: The Saga of the LCS(L) Ships from Iwo Jima to Vietnam,'' will discuss and sign his book. Tuesday at 7 p.m. Free. 44 Brick Plaza, Brick. (732) 255-6600.

BARNES & NOBLE Jerome L. Cohen, author of ''The Gravestone Accord,'' will discuss and sign his book. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Robert Espinosa, director of the MINDsolutions Hypnosis Center in Clifton, will discuss hypnotherapy. Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. 160 Route 17 North, Paramus. (201) 261-6995.
BOOKENDS BOOKSTORE Jane Heller, author of ''Name Dropping,'' will discuss and sign her book. Next Sunday at 1 p.m. 232 East Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood. (201) 445-0726.
Etc.

FLAT ROCK BROOK NATURE CENTER ''Spring Strolls,'' guided mile walk. Wednesday, 10 to 11 a.m. Fee: $3. Pre-registration required. ''Sunset Hiking Series.'' Today at 6:30 p.m. Fee: $3. 443 Van Nostrand Avenue, Englewood. (201) 567-1265.

JURIED AMERICAN INDIAN ARTS FESTIVAL 150 fine American Indian artists and entertainers, representing 50 tribes. Today and tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Powhatan Renape Nation. Admission: $10; $5 for children, 6 to 12, and older people; free for children under six. (609) 261-4747.
MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN HUNGARIAN FOUNDATION 25th Annual Hungarian Festival. Saturday, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free. Somerset Street, between Division and Bethany Streets, New Brunswick. (732) 846-5777.

NEW JERSEY INTERNATIONAL FILM FESTIVAL SUMMER 2000 ''The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg,'' the 1999 documentary about the Jewish baseball hero from the Bronx. Friday through next Sunday at 7 p.m. Aviva Kempner, producer and director of the documentary, will discuss the film next Sunday. Rutgers University, Scott Hall 123, College Avenue and Hamilton Street, New Brunswick. Tickets: $5; $4 for members. (732) 932-8482.

RIVERFEST 2000 Food and Jazz Festival, presented by Riverview Medical Center and organized by the Eastern Monmouth Area Chamber of Commerce. Friday, 5 p.m. to 10 p.m.; Saturday, 11 a.m. to 10 p.m.; next Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free. Take the Garden State Parkway to Exit 109, then Newman Springs Road (Route 520 East) to its end. Turn left (north) on Broad Street. Marine Park, Red Bank. (888) 438-3378.
ST. MARK'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH 14th Annual Art Expo and Auction. Saturday at 7 p.m. Admisstion: $6. 140 South Finley Avenue, Basking Ridge. (908) 766-9058.

TWO RIVERS ANTIQUES SHOW AND GARDEN TOUR Friday through Next Sunday. Antiques Show Preview Party. Friday, 6:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. Tickets: $125. Antiques Show. Saturday, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, 11:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Garden Tour. Saturday, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Tickets: $30 (for show and garden tour); $20 for older people; $10 for show only. Rumson Country Day School, 35 Bellevue Avenue, Rumson. (732) 923-6886.

WEIS ECOLOGY CENTER Beginner Caving Trip. Saturday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Fee: $14. Black Mountain to Boston Mine Hike. Next Sunday, 9:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. Fee: $5. Pre-registration required. 150 Snake Den Road, Ringwood. (973) 835-2160.
At the Casinos
All tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

BALLY'S PARK PLACE ''Legends in Concert,'' impersonations of Stevie Wonder, Little Richard, Elvis Presley, Linda Ronstadt and Barbara Streisand. Mondays through Thursdays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 and 10:30 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 and 10 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $25. Park Cabaret, Boardwalk and Park Place. (800) 225-5977.

CLARIDGE HOTEL ''Dream, Dream, Dream,'' featuring songs by the Everly Brothers. Through June 17. Monday through Thursday at 8 p.m.; Saturday at 7:30 p.m. and 10 p.m.; Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $15, Sunday through Thursday; $19, Saturday. Palace Theater, Boardwalk and Park Place. (609) 340-3700.
RESORTS CASINO HOTEL Kansas. Today at 10 p.m. Free. 1133 Boardwalk. (888) 771-1786.

TROPICANA ''Latin Fever.'' Through June 17. Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Fridays at 9 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 and 11:30 p.m.; Sundays at 7 p.m. Tickets: $9.90. Boardwalk and Brighton Avenue. (609) 340-4020.

TRUMP MARINA Sugar Ray. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $30. Train 2000. Friday at 10 p.m. Tickets: $18.50. Grand Cayman. Little Feat. Today at 9 p.m. Tickets: $35. The Shell. Huron Avenue and Brigantine Boulevard. (800) 777-8477.
ARTS & ENTERTAINMENT
